questions.text: Which of the following is NOT included in the classical triad of symptoms for a renal tumour?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fever Haematuria, associated with loin pain and a palpable loin mass, defines the classic triad of symptoms and signs of a renal tumour. However, this triad is seen in less than 10% of patients presenting with a renal tumour.

Highyeild:

Renal Tumour The classic triad of flank pain, haematuria and a palpable mass is now uncommon as most renal masses are detected incidentally. The most common presenting symptom is haematuria. The most common PNS is an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR ) followed by hypertension, anaemia and hypercalcaemia. The most common metastasis site is the lung, which is classified as cannonball metastases.

questions.text: A male patient diagnosed with Renal cell carcinoma has a tumour size of 6 cm limited to the kidney. Identify the correct stage?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stage I Staging renal cell carcinoma is based on size, position and lymph node involvement: Stage I: tumour < 7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney Stage II: tumour > 7 cm in the largest size, limited to the kidney Stage III: tumour in the significant veins or adrenal gland with intact Gerota’s fascia or regional lymph nodes involved. Stage IV: tumour beyond Gerota’s fascia.

Highyeild:

Classification and salient features of subtypes of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC subtype Salient features Clear-cell RCC • Most common subtype • Usually sporadic • May be associated with loss of chromosome 3p and a mutated von Hippel-Lindau gene Papillary (type I and II) RCC • Second most common • Usually sporadic but may be familial • Type 1 tumour has a better prognosis than type 2 Chromophobe RCC • Usually sporadic but may be familial • Good prognosis Collecting duct carcinoma • Uncommon (1-2%) • Aggressive tumour • Arises from the renal medulla, hence centrally located Renal medullary carcinoma • Rare (<0.5%) • Very aggressive • Associated with a younger age and sickle cell trait • Centrally located tumour The treatment and prognosis of RCC depend on its pathological staging. The most important factors are the size of the tumour and whether it is confined within the renal capsule and Gerota’s fascia. Currently, the most commonly used system for staging RCC is the TNM classification.

questions.text: Leibovich prognostic score following nephrectomy for RCC doesn't include?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Age The pathologist often assigns a Leibovich score following nephrectomy – the Leibovich prognostic score runs from 0 to 11 and is based on the tumour’s stage, grade, size, involvement of lymph nodes and the presence of tumour necrosis histologically.

Highyeild:

RCC is the most common solid neoplasm of the kidney. von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome is the most common familial syndrome associated with RCC Pathology : At the macroscopic level, the cut surface of clear cell RCC (ccRCC) tumours is golden-yellow with frequent haemorrhagic, necrotic and cystic areas. Microscopically, ccRCC usually consists of tumour cells with clear cytoplasm arranged in nests or tubules surrounded by a rich vascular network. The transparent appearance of the cytoplasm is due to the accumulation of glycogen and lipids. The most widely used grading system for ccRCC is the Fuhrman grading system, which defines four nuclear grades (1–4) in order of increasing atomic size, irregularity & nucleolar prominence. The pathologist also often assigns a Leibovich score following nephrectomy – the Leibovich prognostic score runs from 0 to 11 and is based on the tumour’s stage, grade, size, involvement of lymph nodes and the presence of tumour necrosis histologically. It should be noted that all RCC types may contain foci of high-grade malignant spindle cells (i.e., sarcomatoid differentiation). Clinical presentation The classic triad of flank pain, haematuria and a palpable mass The most common presenting symptom is haematuria The most common PNS is an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The most common site of metastasis is the lung, which is classically described as cannonball metastases.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperkalemia Paraneoplastic syndromes for RCC Elevated ESR (most common) Hypertension Anaemia Weight loss Pyrexia Abnormal liver function Hypercalcemia Polycythaemia Neuromyopathy Amyloidosis

questions.text: A 20-year- male presents with abdominal distention and abdominal pain for two months. On examination, the abdomen is soft, right lumbar fullness +. The patient is planned for further evaluation. What is the most accurate imaging study for characterising a renal mass?
questions.correct_answer: C. Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Computed tomography (CT) with contrast enhancement A dedicated (thin-slice) renal CT scan remains the most crucial radiographic image to delineate the nature of a renal mass . In general, any renal mass that enhances with the administration of intravenous contrast material on CT scanning should be considered a renal cell carcinoma until proven otherwise.

Highyeild:

Triphasic CECT is the investigation of choice for diagnosis and staging. RCC typically shows contrast enhancement after contrast injection ( a change of >15 HU is considered significant). MRI provides similar information to CT but can be superior at detecting tumour infiltration into the vein wall and the level of thrombus A chest radiograph should be obtained in all cases. A bone scan is necessary for a patient with elevated alkaline phosphatase, bone pain or hypercalcaemia. The treatment and prognosis of RCC depend on its pathological staging.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man has a biopsy of a peripheral lower pole exophytic 4-cm mass of the right kidney. The histology is depicted and is read as clear cell carcinoma. Metastatic workup is negative. He should be advised to YIELD?

options.label: C
options.text: Have the tumour ablated with cryotherapy.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Have a partial nephrectomy. Notice the clear cytoplasm due to glycogen characteristic of clear cell carcinoma of the kidney. Because of the patient's young age, a nephron-sparing approach is preferred . Because the tumour is located in the lower pole, is peripheral, and is exophytic, it is ideal for this approach.

Highyeild:

Radical nephrectomy remains the standard gold treatment for localised disease. Incidental detection of small renal masses (tumours <4 cm)nephron-sparing surgery is being performed. Partial nephrectomy should be the treatment of choice in tumours less than 4 cm, in well-selected tumours between 4 and 7 cm, in bilateral tumours, in tumours in solitary kidneys and in patients with pre-existing renal dysfunction. Because of the limitation of ischaemia time, minimally invasive techniques should be reserved for tumours with non-complex anatomy, as predicted by nephelometry scores. Alternative techniques such as surveillance, cryoablation or radiofrequency ablation of small renal tumours may be offered in patients with high surgical risk (e.g. elderly patients and patients with multiple comorbidities). Active surveillance is based on the fact that most incidental tumours detected in the elderly grow slowly and have a low chance of local invasion or metastasis. Radical nephrectomy Classically, radical nephrectomy involves the removal of the entire kidney enclosed in Gerota’s fascia with the ipsilateral adrenal gland and regional lymphadenectomy. Most are now performed laparoscopically, and the adrenal is spared if there is no involvement on CT/MRI.

These tumours are not sensitive to radiation therapy, cryotherapy does not have a long-term extended follow-up, and targeted chemotherapy is not appropriate for a surgically curable lesion Option B: Radical nephrectomy remains the standard gold treatment for localised disease.

More recently, targeted therapy in the form of immune checkpoint inhibitors and anti-programmed death 1/programmed death ligand-1 inhibitors have been used.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a 5-cm RCC in the upper pole of a solitary right kidney and a single 3-cm right lower lung metastasis. What is the best treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Initial targeted therapy, then partial nephrectomy

options.label: D
options.text: Simultaneous partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Simultaneous partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Simultaneous partial nephrectomy and pulmonary lobectomy The subset of patients with metastatic RCC and solitary metastasis, estimated at between 1.6% and 3.2% of patients, may benefit from nephrectomy with resection of the metastatic lesion. This patient also needs a partial nephrectomy to preclude the need for dialysis.

Highyeild:

A chest radiograph should be obtained in all cases. The most common site of metastasis is the lung and is described as canon ball secondaries. Up to one-third of patients with RCC will present with disseminated disease. The International Metastatic Renal Cell Carcinoma Database Consortium risk stratification classifies a patient with metastases into risk groups based on performance status, time from diagnosis to systemic therapy, haemoglobin levels, calcium levels and platelet and neutrophil counts. The median survival of the good-risk group is little more than 3.5 years, compared with just under two years in the intermediate-risk group. The expected median survival of the poor-risk group is just over seven months. Tyrosine kinase inhibitors inhibit vascular endothelial growth factors (e.g. sunitinib, pazopanib), and these drugs have improved survival in metastatic ccRCC. RCC is an immunogenic tumour and responds to immunotherapy. The frst generation of agents were interleukins and interferons. More recently, targeted therapy in the form of immune checkpoint inhibitors and anti-programmed death 1/programmed death ligand-1 inhibitors have been used. Cytoreductive nephrectomy may be beneficial in suitable and intermediate-risk patients. Palliative nephrectomy may be considered for intractable haematuria, pain and symptomatic PNS. Angioembolisation of renal tumours can be performed in medically unfit patients with intractable haematuria.

questions.text: A 50-year female presents with complaints of abdominal mass and haematuria, on further evaluation, diagnosed as renal cell carcinoma. She underwent a nephrectomy for the same. Which of the following is the most important prognostic indicator in RCC?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pathological staging The pathologic stage has proved to be the single most important prognostic factor for RCC. The RCC TNM staging system clearly distinguishes between patient groups with different predicted cancer-specific outcomes confirming that the extent of locoregional or systemic disease at diagnosis is the primary determinant of products for this disease.

Highyeild:

The treatment and prognosis of RCC depend on its pathological staging. The most important factors are the size of the tumour and whether it is confined within the renal capsule and Gerota’s fascia. Involvement of the lymph nodes, renal sinus and vein wall is associated with a poorer prognosis than the presence of tumour thrombus in the renal vein or IVC. Currently, the most commonly used system for staging RCC is the TNM. ccRCC is histologically an adenocarcinoma arising from the proximal renal tubular epithelium. They are slow growing and bulge out of the renal contour. Most are solitary, but bilateral and multiple tumours are found in familial RCC. The prognosis of ccRCC varies depending on histopathological features, such as nuclear grading. Other histological variants are papillary RCC, chromophobe RCC and, rarely, collecting duct carcinoma and renal medullary carcinoma. The tumour can spread directly, invading the perinephric tissue through the capsule or, at times, extending into the renal vein as a tumour thrombus. Vein wall invasion is associated with poor prognosis.

Extraedge:

Prognostic factors ● Pathologic stage is single most important prognostic factor ● Lymph node involvement is a poor prognostic factor Staging and grading ● TNM (preferred) and Robson's staging are used for RCC ● Fuhrman histological system is used for grading

questions.text: A 60-year- male complained of loin pain, haematuria, and abdominal distention. On further evaluation, he was diagnosed with bilateral renal cell carcinoma. Which of the following conditions presents with bilateral renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Von Hippel Lindau disease Von Hippel Lindau disease RCC develops in about 50% of patients with VHL disease and is distinctive for early age at onset (often in the third to fifth decades of life) and bilateral and multifocal involvement. With improved management of the central nervous system manifestations, RCC has become the most common cause of mortality in patients with VHL disease (3p25 location). Polycythaemia is a characteristic feature in VHL due to erythropoietin production by hemangioblastoma and RCC.

Highyeild:

Von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome is RCC's most common familial syndrome. VHL disease is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is characterised by multiple pathologies, including clear-cell RCC (ccRCC), phaeochromocytoma, retinal angiomas and haemangioblastomas of the brainstem, cerebellum or spinal cord

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A & B. Adenoma sebaceous (tuberous sclerosis, Bourneville disease) These facial papules (angiofibroma) are red-brown depending on skin colour and usually appear on the nasolabial folds, cheek and chin. They usually appear in children before ten and increase in size and number until adolescence. Cosmetic removal by argon or pulsed-dye lasers or scalpel is indicated. Option: D . Neurofibromas are benign tumours that arise from the nerve sheath. There are three significant types of neurofibroma: cutaneous, spinal and plexiform. In 90% of cases, they present as solitary lesions, with the remainder presenting in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1), an autosomal dominant genetically inherited disease. NF-1 occurs in 1 in 3000 births and has been referred to as peripheral neurofibromatosis or von Recklinghausen disease

questions.text: A 3-year- the male child is brought by his parents with complaints of abdominal distention and haematuria. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with Wilms tumour. Which of the following is the Commonest presentation of Wilms tumour?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abdominal lump The typical presentation is a child aged between 1 and 4 years of either gender with a large, palpable abdominal mass that may cross the midline.

Highyeild:

Nephroblastoma (Wilms’ tumour) This is the most common tumour in childhood, accounting for 5% of all childhood cancers. They are bilateral in 5% of cases and familial in 1%. Pathology : The tumour has mixed elements derived from the embryonic nephrogenic tissue, namely blastemal or undifferentiated tissue, epithelial tubules and stroma. Presentation : The typical presentation is a child aged between 1 and 4 years of either gender with a large, palpable abdominal mass that may cross the midline. It may also be associated with haematuria, hypertension, fever and weight loss. Pain is relatively uncommon. The large tumour can rupture and present as an acute abdomen. Differential Diagnosis : Other causes of renal masses include neuroblastoma, congenital mesoblastic nephroma, RCC, clear-cell sarcoma and rhabdoid tumour. Investigations : The US can confirm the mass's renal origin and solid nature. Further definitive imaging with either CECT or MRI is necessary to stage the disease. Up to 13% of patients have bilateral tumours. The tumours usually infiltrate the kidneys, and normal renal parenchyma is compressed at the periphery around the tumour (claw sign) . ACT of the chest should be obtained as the lung is the most common site of distant metastasis. Treatment : Current treatment is nephrectomy with pre- or postoperative chemotherapy. Both regimes have a comparable survival of ~90%

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, C & D. It may also be associated with haematuria, hypertension, fever and weight loss. Pain is relatively uncommon.

Extraedge:

A mutation in the Wilms’ tumour suppressor gene (WT1) causes some cases Survival depends on tumour spread, completeness of excision and histological appearance but exceeds 70% even with advanced tumours

questions.text: Radical nephrectomy done for tumour size of 4 cm located in inferior pole removes all except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adrenal gland Classic radical nephrectomy consists of removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland and regional lymph nodes However, in patients with a tumour <5cm in size, located at the inferior pole, the adrenal gland can be spared

Highyeild:

RADICAL NEPHRECTOMY : Classic radical nephrectomy consists of removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland and regional lymph nodes. However, the adrenal gland can be spared in patients with a tumour <5cm in size located at the inferior pole. Similarly, regional lymph node dissection can be reserved for patients with clinically positive nodes detected by CT or during the surgical procedure. It is performed, if possible, as a laparoscopic procedure (most stage I and stage II tumours), but if this is not feasible, then it is an open procedure. Patients with renal vein or IVC involvement by tumour but without evidence of metastatic disease remain surgical candidates. Occasionally, nephrectomy and removal of IVC tumour thrombus must be done in conjunction with cardiothoracic surgeons, using cardiopulmonary bypass techniques for those tumours extending above the diaphragm. Bench surgery and auto-transplantation is performed in highly specialised centres for more extensive tumours in a solitary kidney.

Extraedge:

Most are now performed laparoscopically, and the adrenal is spared if there is no involvement on CT/MRI. Lymphadenectomy is indicated only in high-risk patients with large primary tumours and enlarged lymph nodes.
